awd_titl_txt: Quasi-periodic Water Waves and Their Stability
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the complex dynamics of water waves is essential in many engineering applications, including power generation from ocean waves, early detection of tsunamis, and safeguarding coastal power plants. While pure traveling waves and pure standing waves have been studied extensively in the past, real ocean waves generally contain more than two dominant frequencies and wavelengths. This project will develop mathematical and numerical techniques for studying quasi-periodic water waves. Traveling and standing waves are special cases with one and two quasi-periods, respectively.  The stability of these waves will also be investigated, including stability transitions. Of course, only stable solutions will be seen in the ocean or laboratory, but unstable solutions can be computed numerically, often completing the picture of how the stable solutions fit together. These methods will also be used to compute microseisms, which are geophysical elastic waves in the sea bed generated by nearly coherent standing waves at the ocean surface, and Faraday waves, which are surface waves on water or oil in a wave tank that self-organize into various standing wave patterns when the container is driven to oscillate with a prescribed motion. The numerical results of this project will be compared with wave tank experiments done by Diane Henderson's group at Penn State in the William G. Pritchard Fluid Mechanics Laboratory. Additional broader impacts include course and curriculum development, organization of seminars and minisymposia, advising of graduate students, and development of new computational tools with many applications beyond water waves.

The first technical goal of the project is to devise and implement a generalized shooting method for computing quasi-periodic solutions of differential equations. Several new types of solutions of the free-surface Euler equations are expected to be found, including traveling-standing waves, KdV-like elastic collisions, and NLS-like breathers. Harmonic and subharmonic stability of standing waves and other relative periodic solutions will also be determined, with the goal of studying orbital stability, long-time dynamics, and quasi-periodic perturbations of relative-periodic solutions.  Subharmonic stability will be investigated using Bloch theory in space and Floquet theory in time, with solutions of the linearized Euler equations computed in parallel batches to compute the monodromy operator. Standing-wave analogues of the Benjamin-Feir instability will also be studied. A new approach to computing cyclic steady states and stability transitions of parametrically driven Faraday wave systems will also be developed, along with a new algorithm for computing the Dirichlet-Neumann operator in a cylindrical geometry using tensor products of orthogonal polynomials tailored to the cylindrical geometry and a variant of the Transformed Field Expansion technique. The Arnoldi algorithm will be used to compute the eigenvalues of the monodromy operator for the Faraday wave problem to obtain the largest Floquet multipliers.  The method can track families of solutions through unstable branches to yield a more complete picture of the stability transitions that affect pattern formation. Quasi-periodic forcing of Faraday waves will also be investigated.

por.por_cntn:
A large body of water such as the ocean is often covered in surface waves that travel and oscillate in a regular pattern over vast distances for long periods of time. These waves can have a rich structure that is not characterized by a single wavelength or temporal period but nevertheless exhibit patterns that approximately repeat in space and/or time. A major outcome of the project is a new formulation of the equations of motion governing surface water waves in which there are multiple fundamental wavelengths or frequencies represented in the solution, along with their higher harmonics.

Functions with multiple fundamental wavelengths are known as quasi-periodic functions.  They can be represented as periodic functions in a higher dimensional space that are evaluated along a line or plane slicing through this space. For example, if F(x1,x2) is a periodic function of two variables, meaning that its graph looks the same above each square of an infinite sheet of graph paper, then f(x)=F(k1*x,k2*x) is a quasi-periodic function of one variable, where k1 and k2 are fixed parameters. As x varies, (k1*x,k2*x) sweeps out a line in the (x1,x2) plane. One can focus on a single square of the graph paper if we make the line "wrap around" and come out the left or bottom side when it leaves the right or top side, respectively. This "periodic square" is known as the torus.  We refer to F as the torus function and f as the extracted quasi-periodic function. The key idea of the new formulation is to find equations of motion for torus function versions of the wave height and velocity potential describing the water wave so that the extracted functions satisfy the physical equations of motion.

The PI and Xinyu Zhao, a graduate student partially supported by the award, wrote four papers laying out the theory of spatially quasi-periodic water waves, devising numerical methods to compute them, and studying their properties. Highlights of the research include developing conformal mapping methods to efficiently compute the normal velocity of the fluid in the quasi-periodic setting; constructing quasi-periodic traveling waves using large-scale optimization methods and numerical continuation; developing a new method of detecting bifurcations in dynamical systems and using this method to find bifurcations from large-amplitude periodic traveling waves to quasi-periodic traveling waves relevant to the ocean; developing efficient timestepping algorithms to solve the spatially quasi-periodic initial value problem numerically; and computing examples of water waves with infinitely many wave crests, no two of which are identical, and only some of which overturn when evolved forward in time. An important broader impact is that this is the first numerical method capable of studying the long-time behavior of modulational instabilities of traveling waves in the ocean, where the unstable perturbation has a different wavelength than the traveling wave and grows in amplitude until nonlinear effects prevent further growth, leading instead to interesting dynamics such as rogue wave formation and recurrence.

In addition to studying spatially quasi-periodic water waves, the PI wrote two solo-author papers on the stability of standing water waves to harmonic perturbations and on temporally quasi-periodic traveling-standing water waves. He wrote three additional papers with students and collaborators on rigorous asymptotic models of water waves, on how to efficiently compute the Dirichlet-Neumann operator (DNO) in a three dimensional cylindrical geometry, and on boundary integral methods for evolving 2D water waves with background flow over obstacles and variable bottom topography. The DNO relates the velocity potential on the free surface to the normal velocity of the fluid, and is therefore a fundamental object of study in water wave theory. The methods are spectrally accurate, which means their convergence rates are limited by the smoothness of the solution rather than the order of the approximations made in deriving the method.

The PI advised four graduate students during the award period, and each of them contributed to the research of the award. Xinyu Zhao's work was described above. The PI and Saad Qadeer worked on numerical methods for computing pattern formation and Faraday waves in a 3D fluid in a cylindrical container that is externally driven to produce Faraday wave patterns on the free surface. The PI and Yanhe Huang developed 3D axisymmetric boundary integral methods for studying the dynamics of a bubble rising in a cylindrical tube, which led to new algorithms to regularize hypersingular integrals and to stabilize 3-term recurrence relations for evaluating orthogonal polynomials near the endpoints. The PI and Rockford Sison developed new algorithms to evaluate oscillatory integrals with applications in water waves and plasma physics. All four graduate students received their PhDs during or shortly after the award period, and the PI incorporated several aspects of the research of the award in his two-semester graduate course on Numerical Solution of Differential Equations at UC Berkeley in 2020-21 and 2023.
